content.text: Welcome to your first Dutch conversation! You're at a 'borrel', a casual drinks event. It's the perfect place to meet people. A friendly local approaches you.

data.tip: This is a short, sharp sound, like the 'i' in 'sit', not the 'ee' in 'see'.

content.title: Introduce Yourself
content.setting: You're at a networking event in Eindhoven. A friendly local named Lars approaches you.

conversation_flow.title: Tell him your name.
conversation_flow.chatbot_message: Hoi! Ik ben Lars. Hoe heet jij?

conversation_flow.title: Tell him where you are from.

content.text: Cultural Tip: Don't be surprised if a Dutch person asks about your job right away. It's not considered rude, just a common way to get to know someone.

data.tip: The 'w' is soft, like a 'v'. The 'r' is slightly rolled in the back of the throat, but a simple English 'r' sound is fine for now.

content.title: Talk About Your Life
content.setting: The conversation with Lars continues. He's curious to learn more about you.

conversation_flow.title: Tell him your profession.
conversation_flow.chatbot_message: Leuk! Wat voor werk doe je hier in Nederland?

conversation_flow.title: Tell him which city you live in.
conversation_flow.chatbot_message: Interessant! Een {user_job}. En waar woon je?

content.text: Grammar Tip: To ask a simple question, you often just swap the first two words. 'Jij bent...' (You are...) becomes 'Ben jij...?' (Are you...?).

data.meaning: What kind of work do you do?

content.title: Ask About Him
content.setting: You've shared a bit about yourself. Now it's your turn to ask Lars some questions.

conversation_flow.title: Ask him a question to keep the conversation going.
conversation_flow.chatbot_message: Ah, leuke stad! Ik ken het een beetje.

conversation_flow.title: Now ask him what he does for work.
conversation_flow.final_message: Ik ben een software engineer bij Philips. Erg leuk je te ontmoeten, {user_name}!
